resources.string: "Contacts permissions are needed for providing email completions."
SECTION 7: Exit criteria from study for SAM
SECTION 8: Exit criteria from study for MAM
SECTION B: Screening for SAM Cases
SECTION C: HH Size & Study Participants
SECTION E: Child Morbidity & Care Seeking

Supporting Women and Girls in Pakistan Scaling Up
 Empowerment and Care Strategies to Address Health and Survival
 Centre of Excellence Women & Child Health
 Aga Khan University, Karachi, Pakistan
A119:\t Result of Household Questionnaire interview:
Discuss any result not completed with team leader.
No household member at home or no competent respondent at home at time of visit
Entire household absent for extended period of time
Dwelling vacant or address not a dwelling
HH Having a child of 5 – 10 Years age group with Chronic Disease
HH having a child of 5 – 10 Years age group which is part of any nutrition study
Has the parents/legal guardian agreed to participate and given the consent?

Note: Grades of Oedema-Definition : 1) Absent, 2)Grade + Mild: Both feet/ankles, 3) Grade++Moderate: Both feet, plus lower legs, hands or lower arms, 4) Grade+++Severe: Generalized oedema including both feet, legs, hands, arms and face
If Yes then rank : - Appetite returned (eats at least 75% of RUTF+RUSF)
Poor(Child takes RUTF/RUSF with persistent encouragement)
Refused (Child refuses RUTF/RUSF even after persistent encouragement
Appetite returned (eats at least 75% of RUTF+RUSF)
Not alert(very weak. lethargic, unconscious ,fits or convulsion)
Conditions requiring IV infusion or NG tube feeding
Is child involved in another research trial or supplemental feeding program?
Child has a chronic debilitating illness such as cerebral palsy (not including HIV or TB)?
Child had a history of milk or peanut allergy?
- Child will be enrolled if Yes in Q 2.1,2.3 and Q 2.4 response is 1 “Good” and No in Q 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8 & 2.9

- Children will not be enrolled in the trial who involved in another research trial or supplemental feeding program, are developmentally delayed, have a chronic debilitating illness such as cerebral palsy (not including HIV or TB), hereditary blood disease or had a history of milk or peanut allergy.
Child Date of brith or Age at recruitment
Age at the time of recruitment
Gestational age at birth in weeks ?
Did the child (Name) have any of the following illnesses during last two weeks?
Did you seek any care for these illnesses during last two weeks?
Who did you see for the illnesses during last two weeks? Anyone else?
Did the child (Name) have to stay in the hospital during last two weeks for treatment of any of these illnesses?
How many days did child (Name) stay in the hospital during last two weeks for treatment of any of these illnesses?
What is your mother tongue/native language?
What is the main source of drinking water in your house hold?
Do you take any step to make the water safer to drink?
If yes, what do you usually do to make the water safe to drink?
What type of toilet facilities do you usually use in your house hold?
A. Flush or Pour Flush Toilet
Do you share this toilet facility with other households?
If yes, how many other households use this toilet facility?
Are following facilities available in your house hold?
What type of fuel do you often use in your household?
Is the cooking usually done in the house, in a separate room/space, or outdoors?
Do you have a separate room which is used as a kitchen?
How many rooms in this household are used for sleeping?
Does any member of this household own?
Animal to draw water from dug well
Does any member of this household own any agricultural land?
If yes, how many acres or canals of agricultural land do members of this household own?
Does your household own livestock, animals or poultry?
If yes, how many livestock, animals or poultry does your household own? Ask for each listed animal, one by one and insert 00 if none
Do you have any soap or detergent in your household for hand washing?
If yes, what type of soap do you have in your household?

In what situations do you wash your hands with soap? This is an open-ended question. Do not read the answer choices. After the respondent stops listing times, ask “Are there any other situations where you wash your hands with soap?” Keep asking this question until the respondent thinks there are no other times.
In the past four weeks, did you worry that your household would not have enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, were you or any household member not able to eat the kinds of foods you preferred because of a lack of resources?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks) 3
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat a limited variety of foods due to a lack of resources?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks) 3
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat some foods that you really did not want to eat because of a lack of resources to obtain other types of food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member have to eat a smaller meal than you felt you needed because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any other household member have to eat fewer meals in a day because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, was there ever no food to eat of any kind in your household because of lack of resources to get food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member go to sleep at night hungry because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
In the past four weeks, did you or any household member go a whole day and night without eating anything because there was not enough food?
Rarely (once or twice in the past four weeks)
Sometimes (3-10 times in the past four weeks)
Often (more than ten times in the past four weeks)
Which are the three main (most important) income sources for your household?
Livestock, sale of livestock / animal products
Casual / wage labor in other activity
Cash from Benazir Income Support Programme (BISP)
Livestock, sale of livestock / animal products
Casual / wage labor in other activity
Cash from Benazir Income Support Programme (BISP
Livestock, sale of livestock / animal products
Casual / wage labor in other activity
Cash from Benazir Income Support Programme (BISP)
How many sachets were given to child at the time of recruitment?
Status of child during weekly/fortnightly visit?
Did the child (Name) have any of the following illnesses during last one or two weeks?
Did you seek care for your child for the above problems/complications?
Who checked your child’s health at that time ?
From where did you seek care for your child?
Did the child (Name) stay in the hospital during last one or two weeks for treatment of any these illnesses?
How many days did child (Name) stay in the hospital during last one or two weeks for treatment of any of these illnesses?

Note: Grades of Oedema-Definition Absent Grade + Mild: Both feet/ankles Grade++Moderate: Both feet, plus lower legs, hands or lower arms Grade+++Severe: Generalized oedema including both feet, legs, hands, arms and face
Child appetite test for supplements? Note: Appetite returned (eats at least 75% of RUF/Achamum)
Poor (Child takes RUF/Achamum with persistent encouragement
Refused (Child refuses RUF/Achamum even after persistent encouragement
Child temperature and respiratory rate? Respiratory rate (per minute) 6 months to 1 year <50(normal) 12 months to 59 months<40(normal)
Clinical assessment for medical complications of child?
Not alert(very weak. lethargic, unconscious ,fits or convulsion)
Conditions requiring IV infusion or NG tube feeding
If child has medical complications and yes in Q no 4.7, than refer child to public health facility for management.
Have you received supplements from AKU study team or from any other source for your child during last one or two weeks?
Reasons for not receiving and refusal
How many sachet supplements have you received for your child during last one or two weeks?
How many sachets did your child consume the supplement during one or two weeks?
Not using/ stopped to use/consumed less quantity
Please describe the reasons if child ate the supplement less than the recommended dose, not received or stopped to use? Multiple Responses
Can you show me the used and un-used packets of the supplement?
Did you notice any side effects of supplements during last one or two weeks?
If yes, what were the side effects? Multiple Responses
Are you sharing supplements of (Name) with other children?
If yes, who and how many was/were sharing with?
When you usually offer the sachet to your child to eat?
How many sachets were given to child at the time of follow-up?
No oedema for two consecutive visits (if admitted with odeama
Has not reached exit criteria within 4 months
Minimum of two months of stay in MAM
Has not reached exit criteria within 4 months
